p: The ranking of all of the variables by their importance in the parsimonious model, as measured by the Wald Ï‡ 2 statistic, reveals that the most important variables are CT and patient age, with jaundice and bleeding coming in at a distant third and fourth place respectively, followed by body temperature and the CT-TTP interaction ( Fig. 2A). The odds ratios ( Fig. 2B) indicate that presentation of either jaundice or bleeding are associated with more than a doubling of the odds of death, although their prevalence is low at 5% ( Table 2). Transformation of the odds risks into risk ratios (Suppl. Table S1) yields a more reasonable estimate of 4% increase in risk associated with the occurrence of those symptoms at presentation.
